content.description: This highball face climb up the center of a sweet amphitheater is SHARP!  It's not named Vulcan Tip Rip for nothing.  Crank off the ground with crisp edges and very small foot holds.  Long, sick moves gain ground fast.  It would not be wise to fall at the top.  Despite the pain factor, this is definitely in the running for the best V3 at Pawtuckaway.  It's worth the hike up here to try this problem, but make sure you have some skin on your fingertips when you do.
content.location: Above the Upper Cliff

content.description: Sit start on the large feature to the left of the start for "Chuckies Torture". Head straight up the crack.
content.location: Starts to the left of "Chuckies Torture". On the same boulder with Jugs.

content.description:
This almost certainly isn't a new climb, but it took a bit of cleaning and I've never seen chalk on any of the holds nor is it in either of the guidebooks.  

  Grab the second set of jugs on 'Jugs' and go straight up, utilizing a high left foot, and a long lock off with a small intermediate for the left hand. Match a crimp and make another long move with the right hand to some crimps off the deck, keep it cool for the high top out as the feet are great but the hands are not so great. Other sequences are possible utilizing some worse sidepulls out right, so play around. 

  Can also be done from a sit, which adds a long move to the jugs but no real difficulty.
content.location: Directly to the right of Chuckie's Torture.

content.description: A fun little problem with great movement for the grade. One of the best of the grade in the cliff boulders. Start about 3 feet right of that dreadful v6 crimp problem matched in an incut seam at the base of the arete. Using small feet and interesting layback moves, work your way up the sharp arete to a sloping ledge. From there, you can perform a somewhat exhilarating beached whale to topout.
content.location: In the upper uppers (to get there, see the last part of Christian's informative comment under the Cliff Boulders) you will see a striking sharp arete about 10 feet right of VTR and 3 feet right of 'Good Lord!'.

content.description: Jug haul up the sweet flake on overhanging rock.  Then make progressively harder moves to the lip, and make a sketchy mantle (probably the crux) to top out.  Be solid or have a bail out plan for the top, since a fall could be ugly from the mantle.
content.location: Above the Upper Cliff (left side).

content.description:
A diagonal crack splits this overhanging face.  Perfect undercling fingerlocks, slopers, small technical feet, and hard pulls are all part of the fun.  Start standing with dual underclings and tiny feet.  Make a large move left hand to a sloper on the lip, work your feet, and follow the crack to the right.  Once you grab the jugs, the topout through the notch will feel like cake.  Careful not to hit the tree if you blow it. 

  A sit start goes at V9-10.  The block on the left is not part of the problem.
content.location: This problem is on a boulder sitting between the Font Boulder and the Upper Cliff.  Although it practically sits on top of the Font boulder, it is best approached from the top.  If you can find The Roof, keep walking towards Bean Pole and look downhill to your left.

content.description:
Sit or stand start and climb the splitter crack to the top.

 The crack grows wider as you ascend and takes hands, fist, and stacked hands jams like a champ. Great for beginner crack climbers to practice on.
content.location:
This boulder is located between the top of Lower Slabs and the bottom of Upper Cliff directly off one of the hiking trails that connect the two. For a reference point, when standing at the boulder you can see "The Roof" up hill and to your left. 

 GPS: 43.1178,-71.1783056

content.description: A classic climb up the middle of the face on small crimps! Start  sitting slightly right on small crimps and trend left a little on edges and gastons to a tricky topout. Sharp.
content.location: To the left of the easy slab climbs on the first boulder you come to when exploring the cliff boulders. If you are looking at Chukies Torture walk all the way left.

content.description:
This problem used to have a sit start, but some of the holds have fallen off. There is still potential for a sit start, but it will be hard, awkward and probably not that much fun. 

  In its current state, the climb goes from a squat start, starting with left hand on a bad sloper/pinch (just above a little crimp flake) and right hand on a good crimp out right (see beta photo). Pull off the ground, throw your left heel on and make fun compression moves to a fun mantle.  

  Though short, this climb is a lot of fun. It climbs similarly to 'Throng', so if you like that problem, you'll probably like this one!
content.location: Walk around the left side of the boulder with 'Sitting Santas' on it. This short arete will be visible immediately on your right.

content.description: To the right of the V1 crack in the middle of the Font Boulder, start  on a large shelf at head height. Bump out to crimps trending up and rightward and try to find some footholds. Keep bumping, crossing, or whatever way feels best to climb crimps diagonally to the right eventually topping out on good holds behind the tree. The holds used to topout are good, but a fall here would not be the best thing considering the tree is right behind you. Kind of highball at the end I guess.
content.location: On the Font Boulder. Starts to the right of the V1 crack on a big shelf and moves to the right topping out behind the tree.

content.description: Start sitting on left side of boulder, traverse horizontal crack all the way to the arete and top out wayyy up there.   Keeping your feet on during the jug traverse can be difficult, but rest assured the crux is the topout move to a good hold that you can't see.
content.protection: Pads and spotters for the topout(or you can forgo the topout and call this climb a V1.
content.location: Obvious horizontal crack to left-top of Lower Slabs.

content.description: An obvious, sharp left-leaning arete.  Sit start the base on the right and work your way up to the top.
content.location: Far left side of the cliff boulders (when coming up from the lower slabs).  This boulder is just below Bean Pole on the upper cliff.

content.description: Stand start and figure out the moves to make your way to the top of this right facing corner. A tricky start and finish on this one, makes for some enjoyable climbing.
content.location: The right facing corner to the right of  "Tip Rip Arete".

content.description:
This problem continues the theme for this wall/boulder- technical slabby and vertical climbing! 

  Start standing around 5 feet to the right of the obvious crack that makes up 'Gabber's Route'. Choose starting holds from a couple of different options. (I went with the diagonal flake for my left hand and a high crimp/pocket for my right hand.) Head straight up via technical moves on an array of small crimps facing all sorts of directions. Near the top, the holds begin to run out. Stand delicately on some small feet to latch the distant, sloping lip and finish out easily. 

  This is a good test of crimp strength and slab climbing skills. A fun and worthwhile climb. 

  It should be noted that the crack at left is considered 'off' for this problem.
content.protection: A couple of pads are ideal.
content.location: This climb is located on the Font Boulder, which is directly uphill of 'Chuckie's Torture'. It climbs the face to the right of 'Gabber's Route' and to the left of 'My Way'.

content.description:
Let's be honest. There aren't a lot of truly good cracks to be found amongst the bouldering at Pway. This drives people to do crazy things, like thinking they actually want to climb 'Crack Of Pain' at Blair Woods. Why fawn over that quartz nightmare when you can actually climb a really good, comfortable finger crack? 

  This crack isn't super long, but it is quite fun and challenging, and not even that sharp. (Well, maybe a little. But nowhere near as bad as 'Crack Of Pain'!) 

  Stand start with some good fingerlocks and work your way up through some decent locks and small feet to a wonderful top out jug. 

  There is an easier variation that uses some holds to the left (mostly the arete), but the best way to climb this sweet little line is straight up, crack only!
content.protection: A pad or two. Maybe a spotter so you don't hit the tree if you fall near the top.
content.location: Located above Upper Cliff, in the same amphitheater as 'Vulcan Tip Rip'. This climb is the obvious crack located on the left side.

climbs.name: Good Lord! aka The Tip Rip Face

content.description:
Like crimps?  

  Like really, really sharp, tiny crimps? 

  Then you're in luck because this is the climb for you! 

  Start standing with a few different options- either at left utilizing a good crimp flake or on the right using a high right crimp/gaston. Enjoy these holds because those are the last good ones you will grab until the top. 

  Pull off the ground and try to piece together a sequence that works for you using small technical feet and tiny sharp crimps. If you make it to the good horizontal, either traverse slightly left and up through a crack (harder, scarier and better) or bail right around the corner (easier, less scary, kind of lame). The top is often dirty and covered with pine needles so scope it out beforehand. 

  It isn't a four star classic, but it is hard, technical face climbing. If that's your thing, you'll love it.  

  The arete at right is not 'on' for this problem. This climb only utilizes holds on the face to the left of the arete.
content.protection: A couple of pads. Lots of tape.
content.location: Located above the Upper Cliff in the same amphitheater as 'Vulcan Tip Rip' and others. This problem climbs the face to the left of 'The Tip Rip Arete' without using the arete.

content.description: Stand start with left hand on a jug and right in the crack. Reach high to a bomber fingerlock (crux) and continue up the crack. A sit-start variation is possible.
content.location: On the Font boulder, the obvious finger crack about 15 feet left of the Dike Route.

content.description: This new addition (11/18/15) is probably the best warm-up at the upper uppers!  Start with a good right-hand crimp, a side-pull with the left hand and a good left foot.  Move right to good holds on the arete, and climb it to the top.  The crux is probably the first move or two, and the top is quite easy and fun.
content.location: The far right side of the upper upper bouldering area, just to the right of "Charlie's Crack."  You can't miss it, because if you do, you've probably walked off the cliff.

content.description: A left leaning dike leaves a black streak through the right end of the boulder/cliff and makes for some fun moves.  The holds might be slightly atypical of the rest of the park, but different can be good.  Start standing and work up and left on crimps and edges to a topout that feels a bit high.
content.location: The right side of the Font boulder (a very wide and sloping mini-cliff with quite a few lines) just above Chuckie's Torture and Jugs

content.description: Sit start with a left hand crimp flake and a black dike pinch for the right. Pull on and make a big move up to a war-like sidepull before continuing up the dike feature on some more unique holds until a series of crimps and slopers are reached. Another committing move gains the lip and leads to a nice exposed topout.
content.location: This climb is found on the far right side of the long wall. This is the same wall that is home to "Check Your Head" and "Adventure Baby".

content.description: Start on the huge under-cling and make a big move to the good jugs on the traverse problem "Jugs". Follow the arete up to the top, staying to the right of "Tom's Problem".
content.location: Located on the same boulder with "Jugs". Starts on the arete with the big under-cling feature.
To the left Jugs - on the first boulder that you approach by hiking up the well defined trail from the left side of the Lower Slabs to the Upper Cliff.

content.description: Sit start down and right of the V9 "Check Your Head" in a crack. Right hand high on a big pinch and left hand lower in the crack. Move up and left to a left hand crimp and come in righty using some foot trickery. From here execute a few more moves on small holds and then finish up a hard and tricky v9.
content.location: To the left of "Adventure Baby"

content.description: This problem apparently begins standing, but may be done from a sitstart from the right for added difficulty.  A small edges around head level exist for the hands.  Hike your feet up to something and slap the pitiful slopers above.  Somehow get your weight on your feet, if possible, and crank upwards.  After the slopers, there are essentially no holds for quite a ways.  This is powerful and balancy series of moves...kind of an ungradable problem I think.  But it's very hard and requires strong tendons.
content.location: The left side of the Font boulder (a very wide and sloping mini-cliff with quite a few lines) just above Chuckie's Torture and Jugs.

content.description:
This is definitely one of the best hard crack lines at Pawtuckaway, though it's more about your crimp strength then your crack skills.  

  Climb the aesthetic, arching fingertip crack from a sit on the right. After a few easy opening moves, the business begins. Footholds are few and far between, so creativity and technique are rewarded. As you near the end of the crack, stem across to the left side of the corner, breathe and then finish up the easy corner.  

  Finger size will play a huge role in how difficult this feels. I could barely fit my fat fingers in most of the slots on this climb which made the climbing feel very thin!
content.protection: Two or three pads are useful as it's a somewhat long traversing crack.
content.location: This climb is located above the Upper Cliff in the same amphitheater as 'Vulcan Tip Rip'. It is the obvious arching crack located on the right side of the wall.

content.description: Climb arete to follow the horizontal crack across the face to top out. It's a long, slabby slide down...
content.location: Obvious arete just to the right of Sitting Santas.

content.description: Start with hands on a low shelf. A few good holds to top out in the mud.
content.location: On the corner of the slabby boulder just left of Jugs.

climbs.name: Back At You With The Realness

content.description: A quick power problem.  Stand start with both hands on underclings using the high foot.  Pull on, power out right to the arete, and control the swing.  Finish up the easier arete.
content.location: On the far left end of the Cliff Boulders when approaching from the Lower Slabs, this boulder is almost directly below Bean Pole on the Upper Cliff.  The problems are on the downhill side.

content.description: Start on the 1.5 pad incut rail as for "My Way" and head up slightly left to a sharp-ish crimp.  Mantle this crimp and make your way up the steep slab above.  Stand start
content.protection: The ground is perfectly flat but your feet are about 7' off the ground at the crux.  One well placed pad is sufficient.
content.location: On the Font boulder.  The head height rail is about 10' left of Gabber's Route (obvious vertical crack) and 5' left of the tree.  Same start hold as "My Way"

content.description: This area can be a great stop off to burn out, project hard, or just warm-up for Boulder Natural. Grades range from V0 to V11, and great climbs at many of those grades. This area is frequently forgotten about and will be empty even when Boulder Natural and Round Pond are crowded.
